item.title: How Google got away with charging publishers more than anyone else
item.description:
For years, Google took the same 20 percent commission for ad transactions that ran through its platform, even though it was higher than what any other industry player charged. Executives privately worried the fee was difficult to defend. Now, the Justice Department argues it’s a key sign of Google’s monopoly over online ads.

Google’s so-called take rate took center stage on the last day of week one in the Justice Department’s second antitrust trial against Google. Citing internal Google documents and the testimony of former Google sell-side ads executive Chris LaSala, the DOJ sought to demonstrate that Google never experienced any real pricing pressure due to its unshakable dominance in the market, despite knowing its fee was higher than...

Continue reading…
item.dc:creator: Lauren Feiner

item.title: Salesforce Ventures ups its AI fund to $1 billion, doubling it again
item.description:
Salesforce Ventures just doubled its AI fund with another $500 million, and is helping San Francisco grow its attraction as the city for AI startups.

item.title: Amazon mandates full five-day return to office
item.description:
Amazon CEO Andy Jassy sent a memo to the company’s employees Monday morning, calling for a full return to office at the start of 2025. For the last fifteen months, Amazon employees have been expected to work in the office three days per week. Now, Jassy expects five days of in-person work from employees, with […]

item.title: Apple Starts Rolling Out iOS 18: How To Download, List Of Eligible Devices
item.description: While Apple has announced September 16 as the official release date for iOS 18, the rollout may take some more time depending on your geographical location and other factors

item.title: Apple’s big iOS 18 update is now available for your iPhone
Microsoft Copilot can now help with Excel formulas, make PowerPoints, and more
item.description: At the Microsoft 365 Copilot livestream event, the tech giant unveiled the next phase of its AI-powered tools, which include automating Excel data analysis, PowerPoint design, and more.
